instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2396: What is 820-2396? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.C1803: What is C1803? Capacitor to ground on RTC_RESET_L on machines from 2009-2012, RTC_RESET_L needs to be high for system to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has green light. Seemed to of charged a dead battery. Zero evidence of liquid damage. Won't turn on. 
Ppbus g3h is 12.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high at 3.4v

im guessing this is why we are not turning on. I tried shorting it to ground as I assume that would be like doing an smc reset but no change in anything. 
Figure I have to figure out <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> before going any further. 
Is it more likely a faulty smc causing this high reading or <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> which as far as I can tell is working as it should. 
Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message: What does the L mean on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>? In otherwords, the SMC is being held in reset mode if it is Low (Hence the L). 3.4 is normal. PPBUS is a little low. What is reistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the ISL? (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message: Battery indicator working? Checked all rails for short? Voltage on <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03? <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
Ok sorry the delayed reply, this got pushed to the side seeing as though it’s a personal goal.
Understand the smc reset L now. My understanding of it was reversed. 
So made a mistake. Went to measure resistance of pin 17/18 of the ISL. Charger was still plugged in and I made smoke.. Pads 16/17/18 all disinter-grated. I have an ISL from another board on the there with jumpers made.
I get a green light, no orange light and laptop won’t power on.


Now to answr the questions.
Resitance over pin 17/18 is 1.6k ohms.
Pin 27/28 is 20.3 ohms
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.5v with charger plugged in 11.3v battery only
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is back and 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.4v
Battery indicator is working
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR> is 3.4v as is <CAPACITOR>C1803</CAPACITOR>

And there you go. Just found <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> all over the place. It  drops from 3 to 0 and everything in between. 

Going to go look at that now. Thanks for the questions Duke. I’ll write back if/when I get stuck next!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message: Resitance over pin 17/18 is 1.6k ohms, tell me what is wrong about that...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
I think it should be about 3ohms shouldn’t it?? 
Anyway its a piece of shit this thing. Pin 2 <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> beeps to ground. 
Removed <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> and pin 4 still beeps to ground. 
So <SIGNAL>CHGR_CSO_R_N</SIGNAL> goes to ground yet <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> are off the board. <CHIP>U5420</CHIP> isn’t on board so how on earth does it connect to ground I have no idea.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
With <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I assume you meant <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>?

Also with the voltage measurement of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in your previous post was that before you made the mistake or after?

Are you sure the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is ok? Since that is the only way to ground with <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> and <CHIP>U5420</CHIP> not on the board without it being a internal short. How much resistance is there in Ohm?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
Appreciate the reply man. Yes 2936 is what I meant sorry.

After I made the mistake I took those measurements. I have pretty much given up on this though, it's a mind fucking rabbits hole I've concluded.

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> isn't even on the board, neither is <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> or <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>. <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is also off the board.

When I touched ground and pin 2 pad of <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> it would beep. When I touched on <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> and ground it would also beep. Something else has obviously happened since I took those measurements, as even the other side of F7040 beeps now.. I figured the line is shorted inside the board layers so I cut the via's to the pads on <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>. Pads no longer beep. I start putting it all back together with jumpers and notice that those lines beep to ground again. WTF. This whole time I'm also testing against another board (although dead) and having different and as expected results.

Currently there is no <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> on the board or <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>. Nothing beeps to ground in that area anymore. I put <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> back on, it beeps. I take it off it doesn't, I take one from another board, test continuity of <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> before putting on and no beep. Put it on, touch ground and it beeps. Take it off and pads don't beep but <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> now does. 

And that was it. I went home for the night. I have 12 iPhone touch ic's waiting for me in the morning. May as well stick to what I know, doubt I'll be looking at it again. I reckon that 'mistake' fucked it big time. It only cost me $40 anyway.

Cheers

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
The resistor <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is not going to ground so you probably have a short on one of the other pins. Its a very low resistance resistor for current measuring so it pretty much functions like a wire between all the 4 pins.
Not sure what you're doing

Again what is the resistance in Ohm to ground on all pins with and without the resistor on there? (8 separate measurements)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
Probably short from system side (F7040 pin 2 side) or battery circuitry (<CAPACITOR>C7055</CAPACITOR>-56-57 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR>)?

With <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> on the board, you can simply inject 1 or 2 volts where you find a short and see if something heat.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
So with <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> off the board, F7040 on the board and no <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> I get OL on all pins except pin 1 which is 144ohms.
With <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> on the board it is 144ohms across all pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
With no F7040 I get between 25 and 30ohms across all pins and Pin 2 F040 gets 144ohms.

So short from system side then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message: Upon injecting voltage <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> gets very very hot so will change that next

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
It makes sense that <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> is shorting to ground, it's attached to pin 1 <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR>. Replace it and check. I had sometimes to replace both Fets <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and ISL.

Now, for system side I don't know if résistance 140ohms to ground on pin2 F7040 (fuse removed) is low or normal. I know in diode mode wit fuse on board it should be something like 0.4xx.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> another <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> from donor board. 
Pin 27/28 is 20.1ohm
Pin 16/17 is 2.9ohms
there is 16v on pin 2 <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
0v on pin 3 <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is missing again too
and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is now 0.5v

i replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> three times. All from donor board. Does anyone wanna help me persist with this otherwise I have to give up unfortunately.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2396</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead smc?
threads.message:
Alright so think about it, Pin 3, <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is 0v... Thats not right
Whats the voltage of <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>? Check <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR> voltage dividers, <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> is most likely closed or <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> is pulling it down.

By the way I can recommend having a spool of new <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> because you will be replacing this on more devices in the future. Saves the trouble with shitty donor boards.
